title: Lessons Learnt from the Named Entity rEcognition and Linking (NEEL)

author: Marieke van Erp, Faculty of Sciences, Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU)

segmentation: So, um, yeah, this is a Journal paper, so it's going to be very slightly different from the other ones.
I'm not going to go into very much detail on very technical things and systems 'cause over the course of the.
For years that we run this challenge, we had like 40 systems.
Submit it to this, but I think to talk about how we evaluate these things and how do we set up challenges is a very valuable thing to do because obviously we want to know how good our systems are.
Just a short overview for those of you who don't know that Neil challenges.
These were part of the making sense of microposts workshops.
At the time we were focusing on tweets an at the time.
Tweets were only 140 characters and that makes them hard because people have to shorten things.
People use very domain specific abbreviations.
Also, not all tweets are very grammatical, so this makes it quite challenging for standard natural language processing tools because they assume that you have a grammatically correct sentence.
Actually, over the years people have developed a specific part of speech taggers for tweets.
Also specific part of speech sets for example to recognize hashtags mentioned.
But that's only part of the story.

So what we try to do in these challenges we wanted to see what kind of new approaches do you need to actually understand tweets and then with a specific focus on named entity recognition, an event recognition an linking.
I've got 3 examples of tweets.
Of different kinds of sports, so there's probably a contingent of people here that will immediately understand what the middle tweet is about.
And if I'm correct, it's cricket right?
The top one is baseball, and the lower one, I think is a football soccer, as they would call it here.
But I mean field Hockey has a World Cup as well, so you need all this background information to sort of know this so you can know that that sounds good.
Giants if you know that there are baseball team, you can immediately place it into that domain, but that's hard for systems.
And.
We actually did because this task was run over four years.
It evolved as well.
So the first iteration was only named entity recognition and we use the Connell for classes.
So person, location, organization and miscellaneous, and then in the years that followed, we expanded this to A7 classes that were derived from the Nerd Ontology.
And that also included if Entanet had the miscellaneous class split out into several different classes, because miscellaneous is just one big heap that you can throw everything on.
That's interesting, but you don't really want to classify what it is.
But of course it's very interesting to do, and then actually also named entity linking was introduced in 2014 and we actually updated that surfaced.
We went to the PDF 3.9 then to a 2014 and actually in the last iteration.

We also included nil clustering, so if you if there was no DPD resource that was relevant to a particular entity or event, but it was mentioned in several tweets, the participants also had to identify like hey, there's no DPD resource in this, but it's about the same event, or about the same entity.
And that's quite complicated, quite hard.
And this is really cross domain task.
So the natural language processing community has been doing this and similar tasks for quite awhile, but they take a slightly different approach to these things in the semantic web community.
Obviously machine learning is a very important approach to handle these things, but you know, training data.
Creating training data is very, very hard and that's when knowledge base can come in quite handy.
So there's also specially in the last couple of years that the challenge ran.
We really saw these hybrid approaches that try to make the best of both worlds.
Actually, this is sort of been explained by the previous three presenters as well.
Sort of you know what are the kind of the steps that you have, but traditional year text and a knowledge base go in.
You try to detect mentions you try to type them, you try to detect potential candidates for the linking, then make a final ranking.
Make a final selection and no clustering at the end.
And also some systems.
They for example do two things in one go or they try to combine it.
Because obviously if you try to do this in a purely sequential fashion, you might not have all the information that you need at an early step in the process, so we also seeing some variation there.
So we also 'cause this is a server kind of a survey paper, so in a few slides I'm going to show you some different challenges that ran next to the Neil Challenge.

She's sort of give an overview of the views well and we see that there are different types of evaluations that are being performed, so the easy one sort of is end to end and you just say you know I want to.
I want you to recognize and link these entities and I'm just going to say at the end how many links did you correctly.
Create.
Now the problem is it's not very insightful.
So if you made an error and you mention detection at the start, it might propagate on, but you don't know where the error is coming from.
So the best thing to do, but it's also the most expensive thing to do, and it's not happening very much is that you do a step and evaluation every step of the way.
How you mention detection, you're just going to evaluate that your candidate selection going to valuate that.
But it's we don't see it much in challenges.
And also if you start combining tasks in your system then you can't really do that evaluation.
So actually what we mostly see is the partial end to end where people say we're going to evaluate the named entity recognition.
We're going to evaluate the linking and we're going to do the final evaluation.

We rely a lot on traditional named entity recognition in our gold standard creation, so we don't do as much with super fine grained entity types that you might find in Jago or DB Pedia.
And then also what is interesting to see?
For those of you who don't know that much about the Natural Express community, but they.
Very often still look at the document as is so they would not necessarily link to an external knowledge base.
But see if what kind of coreference links can we make within documents.

So that's also another interesting difference between some of these different tasks and that also makes it very difficult to compare what is happening across all these different communities and also across these different tasks.

About our datasets, where we actually did from 2014 on is build on top of the previous years data set, so the first one, really the first go at it.
It was just named entity recognition as I mentioned about 4000 tweets just randomly drawn from the Twitter firehose.
And a train test split.
Then in 2014 where the linking was introduced, there were three and a half thousand tweets.
Pulled out through the big project and we do sort of made a selection to get sort of clusters of events, so there were the London riots and death of Amy Winehouse was in there for example.
And there was also a training and test split and from then on.
What we did is we included the 2014 tweets in the training set of the 2015 challenge.
We added some knew tweets as development data set and then the test data set was also new tweets that we pulled in.
For the 2015 challenge and actually the same thing for 2016.
OK, this sometimes stops working.

Right?

It's quite hard as you can see in these top two tables to get a really good balance between the different entity types that you have.
So here you see in bold for example, that in our training data in 2016 the majority of the person and the entities were of type person.
But in our development and test data the majority was product so.
This is partly because of the way we collected tweets.
It's also that the organizers of the task were different every year.
And also we wanted to try different things like just user, Twitter firehose or try to search for different particular hashtags.
That creates some imbalances and one of the big problems that we have with a lot of data sets in entity linking.
Is that?
The variation is not very high, so we've got two measures confuse ability, which is a measure of the number of surface forms entity can have.

So how many words do you have to refer to the same entity?

So there's not that many Barack Obama's but there are a lot of John Smiths.

Extra difficulty we put in there.

Little bit about what we saw from the different systems, so people really went to normalizing tweets.
That is something they did a lot, so removing hashtags or trying to write out the full names of people for the Twitter profiles that they use because that could give you some information.
Using knowledge bases more and more to overcome the data bottleneck, people are also using hierarchical clustering.
Also, in the first couple of runs we saw more off the shelf systems that people were using, but it's getting actually more and more custom built systems.
